1. Task: text classification

Naive Bayes is an example of supervised machine learning, and shares many similarities with the logistic regression method

Why Naive? å•çº¯åœ°é è¯é¢‘ â†’ æ¦‚ç‡

this method makes the assumption that the features(æ¯”å¦‚ å¥ä¸­çš„è¯å‰åæ˜¯æœ‰å…³ç³»çš„ï¼Œæˆ–è€…è¯´æœ‰æŸäº›è¯æ€»æ˜¯å¸¸è§ä¼´éšå‡ºç°çš„ï¼Œè¿™äº›ç›¸å…³æ€§ä¼šå½±å“è¯é¢‘) youâ€™re using for classification are all independent, which in reality is rarely the case.

(ä¸è¶³)Naive çš„2ä¸ªç†æƒ³å‰æ
1. å¿½è§†æœ¬èº«å¤šä¸ªè¯çš„å…³è”æ€§

Some words â‘ often appear together and/or they might also â‘¡be related to the thing theyâ€™re always describing.

These words in a sentence are not always necessarily independent of one another, but Naive Bayes assumes that they are. This could lead you to under or over estimates the conditional probabilities of individual wordâ€”â€”ä¸€èˆ¬æŠŠå¸¸å¸¸ä¸€èµ·å‡ºç°çš„è¯ï¼Œå½“åšäº’ç›¸ç‹¬ç«‹ï¼Œæ›´å¤šæ˜¯underestimateå®ƒä»¬çš„æ¡ä»¶æ¦‚ç‡. 2. å„ä¸ªç±»æ¯”ä¾‹ä¸å‡åŒ€åˆ†å¸ƒçš„åŸå§‹æ•°æ®é›† distribution of the training data sets

A good data set will contain the same proportion of positive and negative tweets as a random sample would. Most of the available annotated corpora are artificially balanced just like the data set youâ€™ll use for the assignment.

Howver, in the real tweet stream, positive tweet is sent to occur more often than their negative counterparts. One reason for this is that negative tweets might contain content that is banned by the platform or muted by the user such as inappropriate or offensive vocabulary. Assuming that reality behaves as your training corpus, this could also result in a very optimistic or very pessimistic modelâ€”â€”ä¸€æ ·å½±å“äº†prevalence p(pos) p(neg)ï¼Œè¿›è€Œå½±å“æ¨¡å‹

Step1: Transfor vector by matrix

find a transformation matrix from English to French vector space embeddings.

Such a transformation matrix is a matrix that rotates and scales vector spacesâ€”â€”å›å¿†ã€Šçº¿æ€§ä»£æ•°çš„æœ¬è´¨ã€‹

FèŒƒæ•°æ˜¯é’ˆå¯¹çŸ©é˜µè€Œè¨€çš„ï¼Œå…·ä½“å®šä¹‰å¯ä»¥ç±»æ¯”å‘é‡çš„L2èŒƒæ•°

å½“ç„¶åœ¨MLä¸­ï¼Œä¸ºäº†ç®€åŒ–è®¡ç®—(å› ä¸ºèŒƒæ•°åªæ˜¯ç”¨äºæœ€ä¼˜åŒ–)ï¼Œå¯ä»¥ä¸å¼€æ–¹è€Œæ˜¯ä¿ç•™å¹³æ–¹

æ‹“å±•ï¼Œ3 main vector transformationsçš„å‡ ä½•æ„ä¹‰

(æ›´å¤šï¼Œè¯·å›å¿†ã€Šçº¿æ€§ä»£æ•°çš„æœ¬è´¨ã€‹)

  • Scaling

Step 2: å¯»æ‰¾æœ€ç›¸ä¼¼çš„å‡ ä¸ªç¿»è¯‘ç»“æœby KNN

å› ä¸ºword embeddingç©ºé—´ä¸ä¸€å®šæœ‰ï¼Œå’Œmatrixè½¬æ¢çš„ç»“æœæ•°å€¼ä¸€æ¨¡ä¸€æ ·çš„è¯å‘é‡ï¼Œä¸”å­˜åœ¨è¿‘ä¹‰è¯â€”â€”æ‰€ä»¥ä¸€èˆ¬æ˜¯ä¼šè¾“å‡ºå‡ ä¸ªæœ€è¿‘ä¼¼çš„è¯å‘é‡ï¼Œä¾›é€‰æ‹©ã€‚è¿™é‡Œä¼šç”¨åˆ°KNNç®—æ³•

æ”¹è¿›ç‰ˆ faster approximate KNN
å¯å‘æ€è·¯ï¼šç©ºé—´åˆ’åˆ†

(ä¸‹å›¾åªæ˜¯ç®€å•çš„2Dç©ºé—´) slice the space into regions: you could search just within those regions. When you think about organizing subsets of a dataset efficiently, you may think about placing your data into buckets

If you think about buckets, then youâ€™ll definitely want to think about hash tables.

æå‡KNNï¼Œå¤„ç†é«˜ç»´æ•°æ®çš„æ•ˆç‡ï¼šLocality Sensitive Hashing

æœ¬è´¨æ˜¯ a hash function, to be locality sensitive; an algorithmic technique that hashes similar input items into the same â€œbucketsâ€ with high probabilityâ€”â€”æ‰€ä»¥è¯´æ˜¯ä¸€ç§è¿‘ä¼¼æ³•, â€œapproximateâ€

ç™½è¯å®šä¹‰ï¼šæŠŠvectoræ ¹æ®åœ¨vector spaceä¸­çš„è·ç¦»è¶³å¤Ÿè¿‘çš„åˆ†åˆ°ä¸€èµ·ï¼Œçš„Hashingæ–¹æ³•

Locality is another word for location, sensitive is another word for caring

This is kNN in simple terms: You have a labelled dataset and now you are trying to label a new data point. Find the k nearest data points from your labelled dataset to the new point. The majority vote among the k nearest neighbors is the label of the new point. Add the new point and itâ€™s label to your dataset

One of the biggest problems with kNN å¤„ç†é«˜ç»´æ•°æ®æ—¶ is that å¸¸è§„çš„æš´åŠ›æ³•ä¸‹ï¼Œfor each new data point, you have to calculate its distance from all existing points in your dataset. The LSH technique, differing from conventional hashing techniques in that hash collisions are maximized, not minimized, can be seen as a way to reduce the dimensionality of high-dimensional data; high-dimensional input items can be reduced to low-dimensional versions while preserving relative distances between items. And this problem is what LSH is trying to solve.

So locality sensitive hashing is a hashing method thatâ€™s cares very deeply about assigning items based on where theyâ€™re located in vector space.

æ ¸å¿ƒï¼šMultiplanes hash functions

In order to divide your vector space into manageable regions, youâ€™ll want to use more than one plane. Based on the idea of numbering every single region that is formed by the intersection of n planes.

æ€è·¯ï¼šæ¯ä¸€ä¸ªplaneï¼Œå®é™…å°±æ˜¯å®šä¹‰ä¸€ä¸ªæ³•å‘é‡

å‡ ä½•ä¸Šï¼Œyou have multiple planes and it helps us to divide the vector space into smaller sub regions. But you want to have a single hash value to know which bucket to assign the vectoring. You do this by combining the signals from all the planes into a single hash value.

é‚£ä¹ˆå®šä¹‰ä¸€ç»„planeå°±ç­‰äºä¸€ç»„æ³•å‘é‡ output value is a combination of the side of the plane where the vector is localized with respect to the collection of planes.

5. æ•°æ®å¢å¼ºå™¨å¯¹äºä¸åŒæ•°æ®é›†

å·²çŸ¥ç»™training setæ„é€ äº†ImageDataGenerator, æˆ‘ä»¬åº”è¯¥æ„é€ a separate generator for valid and test sets

Whyç”¨æ„é€ ä¸åŒçš„generator?

Why canâ€™t we use the same generator as for the training data?

LOk back at the generator we wrote for the training data.

  • It normalizes each image per batch, meaning that it uses batch statistics.
  • We should not do this with the test and validation data, since in a real life scenario we donâ€™t process incoming images a batch at a time (we process one image at a time).
  • Knowing the average per batch of test data would effectively give our model an advantage.
    • The model should not have any information about the test data.

ä½†åˆè¯¥å¦‚ä½•æ„é€ val/test setçš„æ•°æ®å¢å¼ºgeneratorå‘¢ï¼Ÿ

What we need to do is normalize incoming test data using the statistics computed from the training set.

There is one technical note.

  • Ideally, we would want to compute our sample mean and standard deviation using the entire training set. However, since this is extremely large, that would be very time consuming.

  • In the interest of time, weâ€™ll take a random sample of the dataset and do the calcualtion.

  • çµæ•åº¦(Sensitivity, TPR)å’Œç‰¹å¼‚åº¦(Specificity, TNR)ï¼Œä½œä¸ºåˆ†æ¯çš„æ˜¯â€œå®é™…æœ‰ç—…/æ²¡ç—…çš„æ€»æ•°â€œï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥å¯ä»¥çœ‹åˆ°æ˜¯(TPï¼ŒFN)å’Œ(TN, FP)è¿™ç§ä¸¤ä¸¤ç›¸åï¼Œå››ä¸ªå­—æ¯å®Œå…¨ä¸åŒçš„æ­é…ï¼ï¼

å…ˆéªŒ(prevalence)åšåˆ†æ¯ï¼šsensitivityçµæ•åº¦(å³æŸ¥å…¨ç‡)å’Œspecificityç‰¹å¼‚åº¦

Similarly, specificity only considers output on people in the negative class.

    è®¡ç®—å…¬å¼ä¸ºï¼šTPR=TP/ (TP+ FN)

PS: å¦‚æœæ˜¯digraphçš„æœç´¢ï¼Œè¿™ç§caseåˆåreverse postorder

(postorder: å³å…ˆè®¿é—®å®Œæ‰€æœ‰å­èŠ‚ç‚¹ï¼Œå†è¿”å›åˆ°çˆ¶èŠ‚ç‚¹ã€‚è€Œ graphæœç´¢ä¸­DFSç”Ÿæˆçš„æ­£æ˜¯postorder)

ä»¥ä¸‹æ‘˜è‡ªstackoverflow

Reverse postordering as the name suggests produces the exact opposite of postorder traversal.

Example

if postorder traversals are D B C A and D C B A

the reverse postorder traversals are A C B D and A B C D

How to obtain reverse postorder traversal

One way is to run postorder traversal and push the nodes in a stack in postorder. Then pop out the nodes to get the reverse postorder.

def predict(test_loader, model, tta=10):   model.eval()   test_pred_tta = None   # TTA æ¬¡æ•°(å¯¹æµ‹è¯•é›†åšæ•°æ®æ‰©å¢)   for _ in range(tta): //       test_pred = []       with torch.no_grad():           for i, (input, target) in enumerate(test_loader):               c0, c1, c2, c3, c4, c5 = model(data[0])               output = np.concatenate([c0.data.numpy(), c1.data.numpy(),                  c2.data.numpy(), c3.data.numpy(),                  c4.data.numpy(), c5.data.numpy()], axis=1)               test_pred.append(output)       test_pred = np.vstack(test_pred)       if test_pred_tta is None:           test_pred_tta = test_pred       else:           test_pred_tta += test_pred   return test_pred_tta

4. å­¦ä¹ è¿‡ç¨‹(ä¼˜åŒ–å‚æ•°)â€”â€”åå‘ä¼ æ’­

ç„¶åè®¡ç®—çœŸå®æ ‡ç­¾ä¸CNNæ¨¡å‹çš„è¾“å‡ºçš„é¢„æµ‹ç»“æœçš„å·®å¼‚ï¼Œå¹¶é€šè¿‡åå‘ä¼ æ’­æ›´æ–°æ¯å±‚çš„å‚æ•°ï¼›åœ¨æ›´æ–°å®Œæˆåå†æ¬¡å‰å‘ä¼ æ’­ï¼Œå¦‚æ­¤åå¤ç›´åˆ°è®­ç»ƒå®Œæˆ ã€‚

3.3 æ¨¡å‹çš„ä¼˜åŠ¿ç‰¹ç‚¹

ä¼ ç»Ÿæœºå™¨å­¦ä¹ ç›¸æ¯”ï¼ŒCNN, æˆ–è€…è¯´æ·±åº¦å­¦ä¹ æ¨¡å‹(å„ç§æ·±åº¦ç¥ç»ç½‘ç»œ)ï¼Œå…·æœ‰ä¸€ç§ç«¯åˆ°ç«¯ï¼ˆEnd to Endï¼‰çš„ä¼˜åŠ¿ï¼šæ¨¡å‹è®­ç»ƒçš„è¿‡ç¨‹ä¸­æ˜¯ç›´æ¥ä»è¾“å…¥å›¾åƒåƒç´ åˆ°æœ€ç»ˆçš„è¾“å‡ºåˆ†ç±»ç»“æœâ€”â€”å¹¶ä¸æ¶‰åŠåˆ°å…·ä½“çš„ç‰¹å¾æå–å’Œæ„å»ºæ¨¡å‹çš„è¿‡ç¨‹ï¼Œä¹Ÿä¸éœ€è¦äººå·¥çš„å‚ä¸ã€‚

3.4 å®æˆ˜ï¼šPytorchæ„å»ºCNNæ¨¡å‹

åœ¨Pytorchä¸­æ„å»ºCNNæ¨¡å‹éå¸¸ç®€å•ï¼Œåªéœ€è¦å®šä¹‰å¥½æ¨¡å‹çš„å‚æ•°å’Œæ­£å‘ä¼ æ’­å‡½æ•°å³å¯ï¼ŒPytorchä¼šæ ¹æ®æ­£å‘ä¼ æ’­è‡ªåŠ¨è®¡ç®—åå‘ä¼ æ’­ï¼ï¼

1. å®šä¹‰æ¨¡å‹

# å®šä¹‰æ¨¡å‹: è¿™ä¸ªCNNæ¨¡å‹åŒ…æ‹¬ä¸¤ä¸ªå·ç§¯å±‚ï¼Œæœ€åå¹¶è”6ä¸ªå…¨è¿æ¥å±‚è¿›è¡Œåˆ†ç±»class SVHN_Model1(nn.Module):    # æ„é€ å™¨ï¼š1. åªéœ€è¦å®šä¹‰å¥½æ¨¡å‹å‚æ•°    def __init__(self):        super(SVHN_Model1, self).__init__()        # CNNæå–ç‰¹å¾æ¨¡å—        self.cnn = nn.Sequential(            nn.Conv2d(3, 16, kernel_size=(3, 3), stride=(2, 2)),            nn.ReLU(),              nn.MaxPool2d(2),            nn.Conv2d(16, 32, kernel_size=(3, 3), stride=(2, 2)),            nn.ReLU(),             nn.MaxPool2d(2),        )        #         self.fc1 = nn.Linear(32*3*7, 11)        self.fc2 = nn.Linear(32*3*7, 11)        self.fc3 = nn.Linear(32*3*7, 11)        self.fc4 = nn.Linear(32*3*7, 11)        self.fc5 = nn.Linear(32*3*7, 11)        self.fc6 = nn.Linear(32*3*7, 11)        # 2. åªéœ€è¦å®šä¹‰å¥½æ¨¡å‹æ­£å‘ä¼ æ’­å³å¯ï¼ŒPytorchä¼šæ ¹æ®æ­£å‘ä¼ æ’­è‡ªåŠ¨è®¡ç®—åå‘ä¼ æ’­ã€‚    def forward(self, img):                feat = self.cnn(img)        feat = feat.view(feat.shape[0], -1)        c1 = self.fc1(feat)        c2 = self.fc2(feat)        c3 = self.fc3(feat)        c4 = self.fc4(feat)        c5 = self.fc5(feat)        c6 = self.fc6(feat)        return c1, c2, c3, c4, c5, c6# æ„é€ ä¸€ä¸ªæ¨¡å‹å¯¹è±¡model = SVHN_Model1()

2. ä½¿ç”¨æ¨¡å‹

åœ¨è®­ç»ƒä¹‹å‰ï¼Œéœ€è¦å®šä¹‰å¥½

# æŸå¤±å‡½æ•°criterion = nn.CrossEntropyLoss()# ä¼˜åŒ–å™¨optimizer = torch.optim.Adam(model.parameters(), 0.005)

ç„¶åå°±æ˜¯è®­ç»ƒï¼š è¿‡ç¨‹åŒ…æ‹¬ï¼ŒPytorchè‡ªåŠ¨è®¡ç®—åå‘ä¼ æ’­ï¼Œè®©æ¨¡å‹çœŸæ­£çš„å®ç°â€œè‡ªæˆ‘å­¦ä¹ â€

loss_plot, c0_plot = [], []# è¿­ä»£10ä¸ªEpochfor epoch in range(10):    for data in train_loader:        c0, c1, c2, c3, c4, c5 = model(data[0])        loss = criterion(c0, data[1][:, 0]) + \                criterion(c1, data[1][:, 1]) + \                criterion(c2, data[1][:, 2]) + \                criterion(c3, data[1][:, 3]) + \                criterion(c4, data[1][:, 4]) + \                criterion(c5, data[1][:, 5])        loss /= 6        optimizer.zero_grad()        loss.backward()        optimizer.step()        loss_plot.append(loss.item())        c0_plot.append((c0.argmax(1) == data[1][:, 0]).sum().item()*1.0 / c0.shape[0])    print(epoch)

2 æ•°æ®è¯»å–ä¸æ•°æ®æ‰©å¢

Note: åœ¨æœ¬æ¬¡èµ›é¢˜ä¸­ï¼Œèµ›é¢˜ä»»åŠ¡æ˜¯éœ€è¦å¯¹å›¾åƒä¸­çš„å­—ç¬¦è¿›è¡Œè¯†åˆ«ï¼Œå› æ­¤å¯¹äºå­—ç¬¦å›¾ç‰‡å¹¶ä¸èƒ½è¿›è¡Œç¿»è½¬æ“ä½œã€‚æ¯”å¦‚å­—ç¬¦6ç»è¿‡æ°´å¹³ç¿»è½¬å°±å˜æˆäº†å­—ç¬¦9ï¼Œä¼šæ”¹å˜å­—ç¬¦åŸæœ¬çš„å«ä¹‰

  • å…·ä½“å¸¸ç”¨çš„æ–¹æ³•å’Œæ•°æ®æ‰©å¢åº“

åœ¨å¸¸è§çš„æ•°æ®æ‰©å¢æ–¹æ³•ä¸­ï¼Œä¸€èˆ¬ä¼šä»å›¾åƒé¢œè‰²ã€å°ºå¯¸ã€å½¢æ€ã€ç©ºé—´å’Œåƒç´ ç­‰è§’åº¦è¿›è¡Œå˜æ¢ã€‚å½“ç„¶ä¸åŒçš„æ•°æ®æ‰©å¢æ–¹æ³•å¯ä»¥è‡ªç”±è¿›è¡Œç»„åˆï¼Œå¾—åˆ°æ›´åŠ ä¸°å¯Œçš„æ•°æ®æ‰©å¢æ–¹æ³•ã€‚

ä»¥torchvision(pytorchå®˜æ–¹æä¾›çš„æ•°æ®æ‰©å¢åº“ï¼Œæä¾›äº†åŸºæœ¬çš„æ•°æ®æ•°æ®æ‰©å¢æ–¹æ³•ï¼Œå¯ä»¥æ— ç¼ä¸torchè¿›è¡Œé›†æˆï¼›ä½†æ•°æ®æ‰©å¢æ–¹æ³•ç§ç±»è¾ƒå°‘ï¼Œä¸”é€Ÿåº¦ä¸­ç­‰)ä¸ºä¾‹ï¼Œå¸¸è§çš„æ•°æ®æ‰©å¢æ–¹æ³•ï¼ˆAPIï¼‰åŒ…æ‹¬ï¼š

- transforms.CenterCrop å¯¹å›¾ç‰‡ä¸­å¿ƒè¿›è¡Œè£å‰ª- transforms.ColorJitter å¯¹å›¾åƒé¢œè‰²çš„å¯¹æ¯”åº¦ã€é¥±å’Œåº¦å’Œé›¶åº¦è¿›è¡Œå˜æ¢- transforms.FiveCrop å¯¹å›¾åƒå››ä¸ªè§’å’Œä¸­å¿ƒè¿›è¡Œè£å‰ªå¾—åˆ°äº”åˆ†å›¾åƒ- transforms.Grayscale å¯¹å›¾åƒè¿›è¡Œç°åº¦å˜æ¢- transforms.Pad ä½¿ç”¨å›ºå®šå€¼è¿›è¡Œåƒç´ å¡«å……- transforms.RandomAffine éšæœºä»¿å°„å˜æ¢- transforms.RandomCrop éšæœºåŒºåŸŸè£å‰ª- transforms.RandomHorizontalFlip éšæœºæ°´å¹³ç¿»è½¬- transforms.RandomRotation éšæœºæ—‹è½¬- transforms.RandomVerticalFlip éšæœºå‚ç›´ç¿»è½¬

é™¤äº†torchvisionï¼Œè¿˜æœ‰é€Ÿåº¦æ›´å¿«çš„ç¬¬ä¸‰æ–¹æ‰©å¢åº“ä¾›é€‰æ‹©ï¼š

  1. imgaug æä¾›äº†å¤šæ ·çš„æ•°æ®æ‰©å¢æ–¹æ³•ï¼Œä¸”ç»„åˆèµ·æ¥éå¸¸æ–¹ä¾¿ï¼Œé€Ÿåº¦è¾ƒå¿«ï¼›

  2. albumentations æä¾›äº†å¤šæ ·çš„æ•°æ®æ‰©å¢æ–¹æ³•ï¼Œå¯¹å›¾åƒåˆ†ç±»ã€è¯­ä¹‰åˆ†å‰²ã€ç‰©ä½“æ£€æµ‹å’Œå…³é”®ç‚¹æ£€æµ‹éƒ½æ”¯æŒï¼Œé€Ÿåº¦è¾ƒå¿«ã€‚

2.4 Pytorchè¯»å–æ•°æ®

ç”±äºæœ¬æ¬¡èµ›é¢˜æˆ‘ä»¬ä½¿ç”¨Pytorchæ¡†æ¶è®²è§£å…·ä½“çš„è§£å†³æ–¹æ¡ˆï¼Œæ¥ä¸‹æ¥å°†æ˜¯è§£å†³èµ›é¢˜çš„ç¬¬ä¸€æ­¥ä½¿ç”¨Pytorchè¯»å–èµ›é¢˜æ•°æ®ã€‚

2.4.1 ä¸€äº›å®šä¹‰(å†™ä»£ç å‰æƒ³å¥½å¤§è‡´é€»è¾‘)

å…¶å®è¿™ä¸¤ä¸ªæ˜¯ä¸¤ä¸ªä¸åŒçš„æ¦‚å¿µï¼Œæ˜¯ä¸ºäº†å®ç°ä¸åŒçš„åŠŸèƒ½ã€‚

è€Œåœ¨Pytorchä¸­çš„æ•°æ®è¯»å–é€»è¾‘ï¼Œ æ•°æ®â‘ å…ˆé€šè¿‡Datasetè¿›è¡Œå°è£…ï¼Œâ‘¡å†é€šè¿‡DataLoderè¿›è¡Œå¹¶è¡Œè¯»å–ã€‚

2.4.2 ä»£ç 

Stepâ‘ å®šä¹‰å¯¹æ•°æ®é›†å°è£…çš„Dataset(è¯¦æƒ…ï¼Œè§æ³¨é‡Š)
# çœç•¥å„ç§import class SVHNDataset(Dataset):      # constructor    def __init__(self, img_path, img_label, transform=None):        self.img_path = img_path        self.img_label = img_label         if transform is not None:            self.transform = transform        else:            self.transform = None    # getter: å› ä¸ºDatasetæ˜¯æä¾›ã€ç´¢å¼•æ–¹å¼ã€‘çš„å¯¹æ•°æ®æ ·æœ¬è¿›è¡Œè¯»å–    def __getitem__(self, index):        img = Image.open(self.img_path[index]).convert('RGB')        if self.transform is not None:            img = self.transform(img)        # åŸå§‹SVHNä¸­ç±»åˆ«10ä¸ºæ•°å­—0        lbl = np.array(self.img_label[index], dtype=np.int)        lbl = list(lbl)  + (5 - len(lbl)) * [10]        return img, torch.from_numpy(np.array(lbl[:5]))    def __len__(self):        return len(self.img_path)# è·å–: å›¾ç‰‡æ•°æ®å’Œlabelçš„è·¯å¾„train_path = glob.glob('../input/train/*.png')train_path.sort()train_json = json.load(open('../input/train.json'))train_label = [train_json[x]['label'] for x in train_json]# å®šä¹‰æ•°æ®é›†å®ä¾‹data = SVHNDataset(train_path, train_label,          transforms.Compose([              # ç¼©æ”¾åˆ°å›ºå®šå°ºå¯¸              transforms.Resize((64, 128)),                ########################## æ•°æ®æ‰©å¢ ##########################              # éšæœºé¢œè‰²å˜æ¢              transforms.ColorJitter(0.2, 0.2, 0.2),              # åŠ å…¥éšæœºæ—‹è½¬              transforms.RandomRotation(5),              # å°†å›¾ç‰‡è½¬æ¢ä¸ºpytorch çš„tesntor              transforms.ToTensor(),              # å¯¹å›¾åƒåƒç´ è¿›è¡Œå½’ä¸€åŒ–                            transforms.Normalize([0.485,0.456,0.406],[0.229,0.224,0.225])            ]))
Stepâ‘¡å®šä¹‰å¯¹Datasetå°è£…çš„DataLoader

åŠ å…¥DataLoderï¼šæ•°æ®æŒ‰ç…§æ‰¹æ¬¡(batch_size=10)è·å–ï¼Œæ¯æ‰¹æ¬¡è°ƒç”¨Datasetè¯»å–å•ä¸ªæ ·æœ¬è¿›è¡Œæ‹¼æ¥ã€‚

entry.title: datawhale-cvè®­ç»ƒè¥-01èµ›é¢˜ç ”ç©¶
entry.content:
è¿™æ¬¡åŸºç¡€èµ›äº‹, æ˜¯Datawhaleä¸å¤©æ± è”åˆå‘èµ·çš„é›¶åŸºç¡€å…¥é—¨ç³»åˆ—èµ›äº‹ èµ›äº‹åœ°å€

æœ¬æ–‡ç›®çš„

  1. æ€»ç»“åŸºæœ¬äº†è§£æ¯”èµ›è§„åˆ™
  2. æ€»ç»“è§£é¢˜æ€è·¯

Master Theoremçš„ä¸€èˆ¬å½¢å¼æ˜¯T(n) = a T(n / b) + f(n)ï¼Œ a >= 1, b > 1ã€‚é€’å½’é¡¹f(n)ç†è§£ä¸ºä¸€ä¸ªé«˜åº¦ä¸ºlog_b n çš„aå‰æ ‘ï¼Œ è¿™æ ·æ€»æ—¶é—´é¢‘æ¬¡ä¸º (a ^ log_b n) - 1ï¼Œ å³è¾¹çš„f(n)å‡è®¾ä¸º nc é‚£ä¹ˆæˆ‘ä»¬å¯¹æ¯”ä¸€ä¸‹è¿™ä¸¤é¡¹å°±ä¼šå‘ç° T(n)çš„å¤æ‚åº¦ä¸»è¦å–å†³äº log_b a ä¸ f(n) çš„å¤§å°ã€‚ï¼ˆlog_b aè¡¨ç¤ºä»¥bä¸ºåº•ï¼Œaçš„å¯¹æ•°ï¼‰å› æ­¤æˆ‘æ€»ç»“äº†ä½¿ç”¨Master Theoremçš„ä¸‰ç§caseçš„ç®€å•åˆ¤æ–­ï¼š
